The Milky Way Galaxy

Like early explorers mapping the continents of our globe, astronomers are busy charting the spiral structure of our galaxy, the Milky Way. Using infrared images from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope, scientists have discovered that the Milky Way's elegant spiral structure is dominated by just two arms wrapping off the ends of a central bar of stars. Previously, our galaxy was thought to possess four major arms.

The annotated artist's concept illustrates the new view of the Milky Way. The galaxy's two major arms (Scutum-Centaurus and Perseus) can be seen attached to the ends of a thick central bar, while the two now-demoted minor arms (Norma and Sagittarius) are less distinct and located between the major arms.

Structure: The Milky Way consists of several main components. At its center is the bulge, a dense and elongated region where older stars are concentrated. Surrounding the bulge are the spiral arms, which are long, curving structures that contain younger stars, gas, and dust. These arms spiral outwards from the center in a rotating motion. The Milky Way also has a disk, where most of its stars, including our Sun, are located. Above and below the disk is the stellar halo, which contains older stars and globular clusters that orbit the galactic center. The halo extends much farther out compared to the disk.

Stars: The Milky Way is home to billions of stars, ranging in age, size, and temperature. The stars in the Milky Way vary from dim and cool red dwarfs to massive, hot, and luminous blue giants. Our Sun is an average-sized star located in one of the spiral arms, known as the Orion Arm or the Local Arm.

Galactic Rotation: The Milky Way rotates slowly, with different parts of the galaxy moving at different speeds. Stars closer to the center take less time to complete a full rotation than those in the outer regions. This differential rotation gives the Milky Way its spiral arm structure.

Interstellar Medium: The space between the stars in the Milky Way is filled with gas and dust, collectively known as the interstellar medium (ISM). The ISM consists of various elements, including hydrogen, helium, and trace amounts of heavier elements. The gas and dust in the ISM play a crucial role in the formation of new stars and planetary systems.

Galactic Halo: Surrounding the Milky Way's main disk is the stellar halo, which contains old stars, globular clusters, and dark matter. Globular clusters are dense, spherical collections of hundreds of thousands of stars that orbit the galactic center. They are among the oldest known objects in the galaxy.

Galactic Center: At the heart of the Milky Way lies the galactic center, located in the direction of the constellation Sagittarius. Within the galactic center is a supermassive black hole called Sagittarius A*. It has a mass of about 4 million times that of our Sun and plays a significant role in shaping the dynamics of the galaxy.

Other Objects: In addition to stars, the Milky Way is also home to various other celestial objects. These include planets, moons, asteroids, comets, and other smaller bodies. Some notable objects within the Milky Way include the Oort Cloud, a region of icy bodies located beyond the orbit of Neptune, and the Kuiper Belt, a region of small icy objects located beyond the orbit of Neptune as well.

Studying the Milky Way provides valuable insights into the formation and evolution of galaxies in general. Scientists use a variety of techniques, such as observations in different wavelengths of light, computer simulations, and space missions, to unravel the mysteries of our galaxy and its place in the vast cosmos.

Studying the Milky Way provides valuable insights into the formation and evolution of galaxies in general. Scientists use a variety of techniques, such as observations in different wavelengths of light, computer simulations, and space missions, to unravel the mysteries of our galaxy and its place in the vast cosmos.

The major arms consist of the highest densities of both young and old stars; the minor arms are primarily filled with gas and pockets of star-forming activity.

The artist's concept also includes a new spiral arm, called the "Far-3 kiloparsec arm," discovered via a radio-telescope survey of gas in the Milky Way. This arm is shorter than the two major arms and lies along the bar of the galaxy.

Our Sun lies near a small, partial arm called the Orion Arm, or Orion Spur, located between the Sagittarius and Perseus arms.
